She’s convinced the reason this debacle happened is you weren't doing the exact same thing you did the first time. She thinks doing the same thing will make you recapture the old chemistry and somehow stop your egos from ruining the whole enterprise. She doesn’t get that it’s always worse the second time around. After the buzz of the initial success wears off, all the tiny differences you thought were cute and endearing becoming irritating and offputting. You begin to wonder, is my partner holding me back? Can I function on my own? One person pulls away. The other gets possessive. It’s a slow, painful unraveling, until one day one of you finds yourself alone behind a desk while the other is the biggest recording artist in the free world. dialogues.text: How come you didn’t come back after walk-on day? You're obviously good enough to play on the team. + eH

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: I don’t know... I'm not supposed to be here to play football. *

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Sure. School's important, but tell me you don't love it. * (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That feeling on the field when the bodies are flying this way and that, and time just stops. It’s like, in those moments, you become...

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Immortal.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Exactly. If you don’t play you can’t know what it feels like. (beat) So you'll play? Jenko hesitates, unsure. Then nods.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: (with a warm smile) Excellent. I see great things in our future, Brad. Great things. Jenko grins as Zook helps Jenko untape his hands. As he d Jenko sees what he didn’t want to see. THE TATTOO - An unmistakable arm with missiles in a car. ZOOK (CONT’D) That’s me. Zook. Cause I’ve got a bazooka for an arm. (beat) C’mon, let’s get some grub. Zook starts off but Jenko stay rooted to the field. ZOOK (CONT’D) You coming or what? Jenko follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt wakes up, grabs his head and moans. He turns to s Maya in bed beside him in her bra and panties.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Whoa! ! a

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Interesting reaction.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: What happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: You don’t remember? Schmidt looks at Maya, baffled.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: No. I remember us dancing, and then leaving, and OH MY GOD WHY ARE

dialogues.speaker: THERE CONDOMS ON THE FLOOR
dialogues.text: (freaking out) Did we have sex last night!? I think we had sex last night!

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is why I don’t drink. They turn to see Mercedes in the bed across the room. Her side of the room is bright pink and covered with unicorns

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Shut up, Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: I'm just saying. It’s all fun and games and then you wake up in bed with a 40-year-old freshman.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I’m nineteen.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: In what, bulldog years? Mercedes gets out of bed wearing a pair of footed-onesie pajamas, grabs her toiletry bag and walks out.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you don’t even remember having sex with me. It’s kind of insulting.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Maya, trust me, if I could remember what was probably the greatest night of my life, I would. (beat) Do you think we taped it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I'd kind of like to re-experience it.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Don’t hold your breath.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Why? Was I bad?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: You were fine.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I'm okay with fine.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Listen Doug, I keep finding you unexpectedly charming, so I’m going to tell you the truth.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You do have herpes.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) No.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You have a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Listen, whatever it is, it doesn’t matter. Go out with me.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Go out where?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: On a date. 2006 style. Dinner. A movie. I’1l do the yawn into the arm around the shoulder. Maybe brush a little side-boob. But we’ll go slow and build back up to this point, and because we’ve already done it, it won't be awkward.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: There’s no way it won’t be awkward.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You're right, it’ll be awkward. Maya smiles reluctantly. Maya sighs

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: This isn’t remotely how I thought this would play out.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Unexpectedly charming.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Fine. One date. God, Mercedes is gonna give me so much shit.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Yeah, what’s her deal?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: She was Cynthia’s roommate. I felt bad after what happened so I told her I'd room with her.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Seems like every time you do something nice you get fucked.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Wow. Really?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Sorry. What I lack in tact I make up for in an attribute to be named later. (beat) Were Mercedes and Cynthia close?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: For awhile. They kind of had a falling out before she died.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I don't know. I think Cynthia was into some bad stuff and Mercedes didn't approve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + eH  4/20/13 45. Schmidt absorbs this, and there’s an awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: So, do you wanna like hug it out? Or shake hands or-- Maya gives Schmidt a quick peck on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’11 work. INT. DICKSON’S OFFICE - JUMP STREET HEADQUARTERS - MORNIN Schmidt and Jenko sit with Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: DICKSON
dialogues.text: What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I don’t want you to get angry, but one of us got laid. Dickson immediately pulls his gun and points it at Jenko, puts his hands up and nods his head towards Schmidt.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s super smart, hella sexy, and an art major.

dialogues.speaker: DICKSON
dialogues.text: Art major? No wonder. (lowering his gun) But I was asking about the case.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: We found the dealer.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Stop saying probably.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: (to Dickson) He’s got the tattoo, but he really doesn’t seem like the guy.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: We went over this last night. He’s got the tattoo, and he was talking about a pickup he made. It’s him.  4/20/13 46.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: You tried to get him to deal to you and he wouldn’t do it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: That's how good he is.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Or he’s not the dealer!

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Tonight is the big rush meeting, so all the brothers will be in the basement. We’re gonna sneak into the attic where he keeps his stash, to prove to Jenko’s the guy.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Or that he’s not.

dialogues.speaker: DICKSON
dialogues.text: Goddamnit... Why is this always so difficult with you two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back with his Koreans, Schmidt talks softly to Korean Jes

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Hey, KJ. You granted my wish and that’s awesome, and I don’t want to complain, but the way you did it was a little monkey's pawish, so maybe I could do it again and remember it this time? That cool? Because having gotten laid and pretending to remember isn’t much better than remembering to pretend to have gotten laid. Schmidt turns and walks out of the church. On the way, an ancient Korean lady tugs at his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT KOREAN LADY
dialogues.text: Hey white boy... fuckin is fuckin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt and Jenko dress in all black.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: This is a stupid idea. He HHH HHH HH OF

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I’m just trying to cure you of your Zook boner.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: I don’t have a Zook boner, I just don’t think he’s the guy.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: And after tonight you will. The Yang brothers appear in their doorway.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: You guys never seem like you’re on the same page.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: We're always on the same page. Our sameness is our biggest asset. That's kind of the key to being great roommates.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: Poncho and Burbank disagreed about everything and that’s why they didn’t last.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Why are you always here?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: We jammed through our work again. What are you guys doing?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: Are you bandits?

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: I bet they’re doing a prank.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: OMG, pranks are awesome. If you guys need help we’d love to--

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: We don’t need help.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Actually...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ride on Vespas. Schmidt with Alan and Jenko with Mik

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: We bought these when we did a semester abroad in Montreal. You know what they call a quarter pounder with cheese in Montreal?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: Royale with Cheese.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Are you guys serious?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: You know what they call a Big Mac?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Le Big Mac! We know! Everybody fucking knows.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: Calm down, Burbank. Alan and Mike crack up again.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: If you see anyone leave the basement, lay on the horn. Jenko and Schmidt hustle to the back of the Zeta house. I flash, Jenko grabs a window sill and leaps to the balcony Schmidt leaps up, can’t even grab the window sill.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whisper shouting) Jenko! Jenko! The door opens and Jenko rolls his eyes and waves Schmidt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the locked attic. Jenko ducks into an open roo

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Where are y--  4/20/13 49. The attic door opens from the inside, Jenko steps out.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do you keep doing that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alan and Mike keep watch from their scooters.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: You see any Zeta brothers?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: Negative.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: Man, I am so locked in right now!

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: Focused like a laser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenko and Schmidt poke around a dusty attic littered with furniture, Fraternity Composites, lamps.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: What are we even looking for, a box labeled DRUGS?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: (a noise) Shhh... They shut up, and we hear the quiet but distinct voices o the fraternity brothers wafting up through the A/C vents.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Next up for pledgeship... Brad Mcquaid.

dialogues.speaker: FRAT BRO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is that He-Man or Sponge Bob?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He-Man. There’s a chorus of ‘definitely’s and ‘hell yeah’s.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Great. What about Doug?  4/20/13 50. There’s a chorus of laughter and ‘are you serious’ and a audible, ‘what’s with those shorts?’

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Guys, he’s Brad’s brother. I doubt we get one without the other. There’s a collective groan and Schmidt’s face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the house fraternity brothers begin to leave the basem

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: Do you remember why we're sitting out here?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: No clue. I was hoping you knew. Alan and Mike start laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: I think the Adderall’s transitioning to the Ecstacy.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: Goodbye work hard, hello play hard. Alan honks his pathetically ineffectual horn twice.

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: (matching the tones) I’m. High.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: (honking twice) Me. Too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt and Jenko dig around, the voices having disappear

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: The Zeta guys are assholes.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: They're not that bad, you’re just a different type of person.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: What does THAT mean?  4/20/13 51.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Nothing. (beat) Let’s go. This is just an attic.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: We could be standing on a mountain of drugs and you'd say it was just an attic.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Fuck you. If he’s the guy he’s the guy I just don’t think he’s the--

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Holy shit. Jenko looks and sees what Schmidt sees: a black ski mask gloves and beside that the gift-wrapped package.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's the package Zook snuck upstairs during the party. Schmidt reaches for it just as they hear someone OPENING LOCKED attic door.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Fuck. The attic door opens as Zook pushes Schmidt out of the at window, and together they tumble out onto the roof. Zook steps in and eyes the open attic window with suspici

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt and Jenko jump onto the back of the Yang’s scoote and they putter off.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Where was the warning?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: About the fraternity brothers?

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: What fraternity brothers?  4/20/13 52.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Fuck, you think we were spotted?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: Leopards are spotted.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MIKE YANG
dialogues.text: Owls are spotted.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You don’t know or you don’t think so?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN YANG
dialogues.text: Giraffes are spotted.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT AND JENKO TOGETHER
dialogues.text: Would you shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt and Jenko walk towards the front entrance of the as Alan and Mike zip away on their scooters.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Look, I don’t care how much you like that guy, you have to admit that was pretty incriminating.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Would you stop insulating that I’m too close to Zook? (beat) You don’t think they saw us do you?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: No. As he says it, POTATO SACKS are thrown over their HEADS, their wrists and ankles are wrapped in heavy-duty duct-ta A car ZIPS forward and they’re both thrown into the trunk

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car bounces along, and in the dim illumination Schmid and Jenko struggle against their restraints. +e * HF *

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: (freaking out) Holy fucking shit, they spotted us and they're gonna fucking kill us!

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: (chill) Seems like it.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Seems like it? Jesus, we’re gonna die. I’m gonna die. I’m gonna die in these shorts everyone hates. They’re gonna put me in the morgue in these shorts. My mom’s gonna identify me in these shorts.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Schmidt, calm down. Be calm.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Why? Why would I be calm? The car stops and we hear people jump out. Footsteps head towards the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh God, this is it. We hear an audible SQUIRT.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I just pooped a little.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: You what? The trunk flies open and their hoods are ripped off. Schmidt and Jenko look up to see Zook holding the gun, wi Rooster and two other brothers, looking deadly serious.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: You already know, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: No. I don’t know anything.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Even better.  4/20/13 54. Zook points the gun at Schmidt and pulls the trigger. A stream of liquid hits Schmidt in the face.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Is that... Smirnoff?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Welcome to Zeta, pledges. Rooster steps up and shoots a fire-extinguisher into the trunk and two others shake beers and douse Jenko and Schm Slowly the foam and spray peters out and the brothers all stare into the trunk, noses crinkled.

dialogues.speaker: ROOSTER
dialogues.text: What fucking stinks?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I shat my shorts. Everyone explodes with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ha, fucking ha. We thought we were gonna die. It's weird that he didn't shit himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt and Jenko sit in front of an angry Dickson.

dialogues.speaker: DICKSON
dialogues.text: I'm gonna make it real simple for you two: Jenko get close to Zook and earn his trust. Schmidt, get in with the dead girl's roommate, find out if Zook's the one who sold her the drug. Tick tock, motherfuckers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt, Jenko and the pledges clean up the house. Schmid watches Jenko take a break and have a laugh with Zook. We see Schmidt and Maya next to each other in class.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Anchoring describes the common human tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information offered when making decisions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: +e * HF  4/20/13 55. Schmidt reaches out and holds Maya’s hand under the table PROFESSOR (CONT’D) Once an anchor is set, other judgments are made by adjusting away from that anchor, and there is a bias toward interpreting other information around the anchor. We see Schmidt at the fraternity, eyeing the attic door, which now has a second lock. We see Jenko and Zook in class, listening to PROFESSOR JA as he reads a quote from Theodore Roosevelt.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR JACOBS
dialogues.text: It is not the critic who counts, but the man in the arena, whose face is marred by dust and sweat and blood... We see Jenko processing the words, which continue as we c to him and Zook playing football.

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR JACOBS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There is no effort without error; but who does actually strive to do the deeds knows in the end the triumph of high achievement, and if he fails, at least fails while daring greatly. Jenko gets run over, his face full of dirt, and Zook rush over and helps him up, as Schmidt watches from the bleach

dialogues.speaker: PROFESSOR JACOBS
dialogues.text: So that his place shall never be with those cold and timid souls who neither know victory nor defeat. We see Maya watching Schmidt on stage at Slam Poetry.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: The fire rages inside me. Burning. Yearning. Unquenched. Entrenched. If a rose bush falls in the forest but no one is there to see it, does it still have its flowers? We see Schmidt and Maya leaving the Slam Poetry coffee sh

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Sorry Mercedes couldn’t make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: + HH HH +e * HF He HHH HH HK

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: I guess we should go back to your place, I can talk to her there.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I know why you want to go to my place and it’s not to see Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: No, it actually is. We see Schmidt in the back seat of Zook’s muscle car, wit Zook and Jenko riding up front listening to Untz, Untz, U

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: You hit the snot out of that kid.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: I know, I almost feel bad. Schmidt leans forward from the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Please, that kid ate us up last year.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: It’s hard to hear over the music.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Yo, you mind leaning back? I can’t see the rearview. Schmidt leans back into the back seat, left out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt and Maya walk through the quad.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You’re sure Mercedes will be there?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Trust me. She never misses an art class, she always sits in front and she always talks to the volunteers. (beat) Are your parents coming for parents weekend?  4/20/13 57.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: They won’t shut up about it. I love them and everything, but they’re like these new-age anything-goes hippies and it drives me bonkers.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't complain. My Dad’s an overprotective maniac. We were super tight when I was little, but now I basically don’t tell him anything just so he has nothing to freak out about. He doesn’t even know I’m an art major.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Well, he can’t be that bad. He made you, right? Maya punches him.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: You're corny... (beat) And I like you.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Um, I really like you. Like, a lot.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Good. Although I’m starting to feel bad about making you do this.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Making me do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmidt stands in a robe on a pedestal in front of a room full of art students with pencils in hand, Mercedes up fr

dialogues.speaker: ART PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: (eyeing the clock) Okay Doug, time’s a wasting.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: ART PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Whenever you’re ready. A long beat... Maya whispers to Schmidt.  4/20/13 58.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: I've already seen everything, so... Schmidt looks at her, looks at the class, and drops the r The class reacts as though they were hit by a gale-force wind. Mercedes closes one notepad and opens a LARGER one.

dialogues.speaker: ART PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Could give us a pose, please? Schmidt eyes Maya, her face inscrutable, and having gone far he goes full Atlas: Hoisting the world above his head After a beat Schmidt glances down at Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: Bummer about your old roommate.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: What about her?

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: The fact that she’s not a living person anymore.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t wanna sound like a bitch, but Cynthia got what was coming to her.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: That sounds like exactly what a bitch would say.

dialogues.speaker: MERCEDES
dialogues.text: Please, I’m trying to concentrate. If you want to talk about Cynthia you should come by the Student Health Center. I work there and we can talk about it in private.

dialogues.speaker: ART PROFESSOR
dialogues.text: Doug, stand still. You're swinging. INT. LOCKER ROOM — DAY Jenko gets dressed next to Zook in the locker room. He po to a few WhyPhy pills in a nearby player’s workout bag.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Do you ever do that stuff?  4/20/13 59.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Used to. But I stopped when Cynthia died.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Oh. Were you guys... dating?

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK
dialogues.text: Me and Cyn? Nah. I’ve got a girl at home. We’re pretty serious.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Oh, cool. I wouldn’t mind finding a nice girl to settle down with. Zook eyes Jenko’s innocent face.

dialogues.speaker: ZOOK

dialogues.text: You don't understand. I lied about my parents not having money for college. I went but I didn't last five minutes. That's why they offered to wait when they dropped us off. I couldn't bring myself to go because high school was so bad I didn't want to be on the outside looking in again. So I tried to be a cop, but I failed at that too.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? We passed the first time.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: You passed it the first time. I failed the physical six times. I didn't pass until you showed up and helped me. Jenk, you said it yourself, we’re exactly the shit- kicking badasses we wanted to be. You’re gonna throw that away to play football?

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: It’s not just football. It’s college. For real. Nobody in my family’s ever had that chance. (beat) I don't want to have to choose, but if I do I'm gonna choose USC. Jenko turns and runs towards the players’ entrance, but a swarm of campus police block his path and the one whose S Car they stole points a finger at them and nods.

dialogues.text: No, I fucking hate him. I hate him so much. I hate that he gets cold when it’s 71 degrees out. I hate that it takes him an hour and a half to order a sandwich. I hate that he gets a little crinkle above his nose when he looks at me like I'm nuts. (beat) I want you to be my partner again. Not because I need you, because I like everything better with you. Jenko starts to respond, but gunfire cuts him off. JET SKIS - Mercedes weaves in and out of the boats cloggi the narrowing channel, Maya zipping behind her. dialogues.text: I figured out why I was so calm. It’s because if I had to die, I was okay dying with you.

dialogues.text: Really. I’m a Yang and you're a Yin, and I thought I wanted to be the Yangs, but when you and I are together we make something even better than Yangs. We make Yiangs. The Ghost speeds into a bottleneck of boats and he and hi henchman jump out and RUN ACROSS THE BOAT TOPS. Schmidt and Jenko follow.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT

Together, Schmidt and Jenko weigh enough to anchor the balloon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya and Dickson sit on the bottom step of the life guard station, watching as Schmidt dramatically reenacts his bi jump for a bandaged Jenko and Schmidt’s proud parents.

dialogues.speaker: DICKSON
dialogues.text: You really like him, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Yes. But how can you have a relationship built entirely on lies? He lies for a living.

dialogues.speaker: DICKSON
dialogues.text: Honey, I know I haven’t been the best father lately, and I’m not gonna make excuses. I’m just gonna try to be better. And here’s proof. (beat, deep breath) I know for a fact that piece of shit honestly loves you.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: How could you possibly know that? Dickson looks his daughter right in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: DICKSON
dialogues.text: Monet, Armageddon, Snakes and Me. Maya looks up at her dad and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maya approaches Schmidt and Jenko.

dialogues.speaker: JENKO
dialogues.text: Would you please tell this idiot that two life debts don’t cancel each other out? Maya laughs and turns to Schmidt.

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: My father told me what you said.

dialogues.speaker: SCHMIDT
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: MAYA
dialogues.text: Yes. Come by my room later. We’1ll do the thing we said we did. Maya gives Schmidt a peck on the cheek and walks off.
